quiz.title: Unit 2: Production Possibilities Frontier (Quiz 5)
quiz.subtitle: 2.5 Introduction to Trade: Benefits of Specialization and Exchange (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Comparative Advantage, Absolute Advantage, Specialization, Gains from Trade

questions.question: A country has a comparative advantage in producing a good when it:
options: Can produce more of the good than other countries
Has the lowest opportunity cost of producing the good
Has abundant natural resources for that good
questions.explanation: Comparative advantage is determined by opportunity cost, not absolute productivity. The country with the lower opportunity cost for producing a good has the comparative advantage in that good.

questions.question: A country has an absolute advantage when it:
options: Can produce more of a good with the same resources
Has specialized in that good historically
questions.explanation: Absolute advantage refers to being more productive - able to produce more output with the same amount of resources, regardless of opportunity costs.

questions.question: Two countries can benefit from trade if:
options: One country is better at producing everything
Each has an absolute advantage in different goods
Each has a comparative advantage in different goods
questions.explanation: The basis for mutually beneficial trade is comparative advantage - differences in opportunity costs. Even if one country has absolute advantage in everything, both can benefit from specializing according to comparative advantage.

questions.question: Country A can produce 10 cars or 5 computers. Country B can produce 8 cars or 4 computers. Which country has comparative advantage in computers?
questions.explanation: Country A: 1 computer costs 2 cars (10/5). Country B: 1 computer costs 2 cars (8/4). Both have the same opportunity cost for computers, so neither has comparative advantage.

questions.question: Specialization and trade allow countries to:
options: Consume outside their production possibilities frontier
Produce more with the same resources
questions.explanation: Through specialization according to comparative advantage and trade, countries can consume combinations of goods that would be unattainable if they produced everything domestically.

questions.question: If the US opportunity cost for 1 ton of wheat is 2 computers, and China's is 4 computers, which country should specialize in wheat?
questions.explanation: The US has lower opportunity cost for wheat (2 computers vs 4 computers), so the US has comparative advantage in wheat and should specialize in wheat production.

questions.question: The 'gains from trade' refer to:
options: The increase in total world production through specialization
The profits made by trading companies
questions.explanation: Gains from trade are the increased total output that results when countries specialize according to comparative advantage and trade with each other.

questions.question: A country should export goods in which it has:
questions.explanation: Countries maximize the benefits of trade by exporting goods in which they have comparative advantage (lowest opportunity cost) and importing goods in which they have comparative disadvantage.

questions.question: If Country X has lower opportunity costs for both goods than Country Y:
options: Country X should produce both goods
Country Y has comparative advantage in both goods
Trade can still benefit both countries
questions.explanation: Even if one country has lower opportunity costs for both goods, the country with the smallest comparative disadvantage should specialize in that good, and both can benefit from trade.

questions.question: The terms of trade refer to:
options: The ratio at which two goods are exchanged
The legal agreements between trading partners
The quality standards for traded goods
questions.explanation: Terms of trade is the ratio at which one good trades for another - for example, how many units of wheat exchange for one unit of cloth in international markets.

questions.question: For trade to benefit both countries, the terms of trade must lie:
options: Between the two countries' opportunity costs
At exactly one country's opportunity cost
questions.explanation: The terms of trade must be between the two countries' opportunity costs for both to benefit. Each country imports goods cheaper than their domestic opportunity cost and exports goods at favorable rates.

questions.question: Specialization increases total output because:
options: Countries focus on what they do relatively best
questions.explanation: Specialization allows countries to allocate resources to their most productive uses according to comparative advantage, increasing total world production efficiency.

questions.question: If Brazil's opportunity cost for coffee is 2 oranges, and Argentina's is 3 oranges, mutually beneficial trade requires that 1 unit of coffee trades for:
questions.explanation: The terms of trade must be between the two opportunity costs (between 2 and 3 oranges per coffee). 2.5 oranges per coffee allows both countries to benefit compared to their domestic trade-offs.

questions.question: The law of comparative advantage explains why:
options: Rich countries dominate poor countries in trade
Trade can benefit all participating countries
Some countries should not trade at all
Trade always creates winners and losers
questions.explanation: The law of comparative advantage demonstrates that when countries specialize according to their relative efficiencies and trade, all participating countries can be better off.

questions.question: A doctor who is also a faster typist than her secretary should:
options: Do her own typing to save money
Hire the secretary and focus on medical practice
Fire the secretary and type herself
Split time equally between both tasks
questions.explanation: This classic example illustrates comparative advantage. Even if the doctor has absolute advantage in both activities, she has greater comparative advantage in medicine (higher opportunity cost for typing), so she should specialize in medicine.

questions.question: International trade is based on comparative advantage rather than absolute advantage because:
options: Absolute advantage doesn't exist in reality
Comparative advantage determines the gains from trade
Governments prohibit trade based on absolute advantage
questions.explanation: Comparative advantage, not absolute advantage, determines the pattern of trade and the potential gains. Differences in opportunity costs create the basis for mutually beneficial exchange.

questions.question: When countries specialize according to comparative advantage, world production:
options: Increases due to more efficient resource allocation
questions.explanation: Specialization allows global resources to be allocated to their most productive uses across countries, increasing total world output beyond what would be possible without trade.

questions.question: The main limitation of the comparative advantage model is that it:
questions.explanation: The simple comparative advantage model typically assumes constant opportunity costs (linear PPFs), while in reality, opportunity costs often increase (bowed-out PPFs), which can limit complete specialization.

questions.question: Free trade based on comparative advantage typically leads to:
options: Increased consumption possibilities for all countries
questions.explanation: By allowing countries to specialize and trade according to comparative advantage, free trade expands consumption possibilities beyond what each country could produce alone.

questions.question: The fundamental reason trade creates value is that:
options: It allows redistribution from rich to poor
People value what they receive more than what they give up
questions.explanation: Trade creates value because voluntary exchange occurs only when both parties expect to benefit - each values what they receive more than what they give up, based on their different opportunity costs and preferences.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered the crucial concepts of comparative advantage and understand how specialization and trade create mutual benefits.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basics of trade but review the key difference between comparative advantage (opportunity cost) and absolute advantage (productivity).
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: Comparative advantage = lower opportunity cost; countries should specialize in what they give up less to produce; trade allows consumption outside PPF.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember: Comparative advantage is about opportunity cost, not being the best. Trade benefits countries when they specialize in what they're relatively better at producing.
